title: What if the Earth's atmosphere contained 100% Oxygen? - Quora

response.answer_text: At 100% oxygen?? Even at 50%, let alone 100%, we would not have forest "fires". We would have forest "EXPLOSIONS". Needless to say, the rate of oxidation (be it biological oxidation, or metals oxidizing (rust) or fires burning... whatever) will depend on how much oxygen is available. Higher concentrations of O2 will cause every chemical reaction that involves oxygen to run faster.  However, it is also important to keep the details of thermodynamics in mind. Since oxygen reacts as an atom, but is present as O2 under atmospheric conditions, the "chemical equilibrium constant" is proportional to the square of the oxygen "activity" (e.g. C + O2 --> C + 2 O --> CO2). Chemical rates of reaction tend to follow the chemical driving force, which is affected by the "equilibrium constant". (All other things being equal. Oftentimes, the kinetics of the mechanisms affect it to. Hence the effects of catalysts, etc.)  But once you've got a reaction going, as with combustion, the reaction rate is basically going to run according to the square of the oxygen content. Increase it by 10%, and the rate will tend to be 20% faster. (1.1 x 1.1 = 1.21). Increase it by 20% and reactions (all else being equal) will tend to be 44% faster. (1.2x1.2 = 1.44). Now then... increase it to 100%?? That is, to increase it by five times? This would (at least in theory) increase combustion rates by 2500% . Of course, in the real world, at some point other factors come into play. But an atmosphere of 100% oxygen (among the many other problems it would cause) would have two immediate and horrifying effects. 1) It would make ignition insanely easy, as compared to current conditions... and 2) It would provide for an astonishingly high rate of combustion, once ignition occurred.  As another poster remarked, consider the dreadful fate of the crew of Apollo 1. (Messrs. Grissom, White and Chaffee). The atmosphere inside their capsule, which was being run through simulation training with the astronauts inside, was pressurized with pure O2. I don't know who the engineers were who made that decision, but it was a bad one. And Grissom, White and Chaffee paid a horrible price for it.  At 100% O2, even a tiny spark can cause every potentially oxidizable material within its reach to immediately explode into flame. Paper, cloth, even wet, green foliage... FOOM! And you can't outrun it. The reaction tends to be so immediate, and its effects so concentrated that many factors which normally inhibit the spread of a fire are utterly overwhelmed. The rest of the ignitable material being too far away. The dissipation of the flame's heat over distance. The presence of moist, cool air tending to dampen the effects of sparks and flame, and preventing them from traveling to the next point of ignition. All of the things that either prevent a fire from spreading, or that greatly reduce it (so that people can deal with it) can be rendered null and void in a high-O2 atmosphere.  As a result, a fire in an atmosphere with enhanced oxygen is a truly awesome (and terrifying!) thing to behold! It is not just a "hotter fire" nor does it move "a little faster". It is more like an entirely different kind of thing.... lunging out like some kind of monster, and engulfing every potentially flammable object within its scope, at lightning speed. Things that normally do not burn, or that only burn when heated extensively, will immediately flash into flame. Human bodies can be engulfed in seconds, as though they were soaked in gasoline. At 100% oxygen, iron and steel can be ignited and burned. (I kid you not. I work in a steel mill. I have burned hot steel... melted it and cut it away... with nothing but a lance pipe feeding pressurized oxygen to it.)  I've read a variety of articles where researchers have tried to estimate the oxygen content of the Earth's atmosphere at various epochs in the remote past. Certainly there appear to be reasons to believe that, at some points, it was higher than now. Perhaps as much as 50% higher (i.e. 30 to 35% O2 instead of 20%). But I seriously doubt that it was ever double today's concentration or higher. For one thing, beyond a certain level, oxygen is not only a fire hazard, it also has toxic effects of its own. But a world with any organic life above the waterline, with an atmosphere that had 50% or more O2 in it, would be a world constantly at risk of being turned into an inferno. All it would take would be a spark.
